You know, Oscar, you're right. It's easy to throw around the term "mass" without really understanding what it means at the particle level.

Essentially, the Higgs boson is like a field that permeates all of space.  Think of it like a thick syrup.  

Particles that interact strongly with this field, like quarks, experience a lot of resistance, which we perceive as mass. It's like trying to move through thick syrup - it takes more effort.

Particles that don't interact much with the field, like photons (light particles),  pass through easily, and we don't perceive them as having mass.

The Higgs boson is a ripple in this field, a way to directly observe the field itself.  Finding it was like finally being able to see the syrup, not just feel its effects.

As for ongoing experiments, yes!  CERN is constantly refining measurements of the Higgs boson's properties. They're also looking for other particles that might interact with the Higgs field in unusual ways.

This could lead to new discoveries about the nature of mass and the fundamental building blocks of the universe.  It's a really exciting time to be following particle physics!
